text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SEVODNYA
- President Boris Yeltsin is more to blame for the lack of military reform in Russia than former Defence Minister Igor Rodionov, sacked yesterday.
- Chechen President Aslan Maskhadov has finally decided not to go The Hague, apparently afraid of leaving the Chechen capital Grozny for such a long time in the current unstable situation.
- Yeltsin has had enough time to convince Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko to change his point of view on the close unification of the two countries.
- The debates between the government and parliament over the governemnt's sequester plan can be resolved peacefully.
- One of Moscow's airports, Bykovo, was closed yesterday because of an administrative scandal.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- Yevgeny Savostyanov, deputy head of the presidential administration, warns of the dangers of adopting an unrealistic budget, saying it would lead to irresponsibility at all levels.

- President Yeltsin has reinforced the Security Council with a troika of reformers -- two First deputy Prime Ministers Anatoly Chubais and Boris Nemtsov, and presidential chief-of-staff Valentin Yumashev.
- Yesterday's Defence Council meeting was sensational, but its results were not unexpected.
- Communists want to launch a criminal investigation into Boris Nemtsov's alleged financial activities.
- President Yeltsin's team is confident its leader will manage to "pressurise" Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko hard enough to reach a compromise over unification of the two countries.
- According to State Statistics Committee data, industrial production has been increasing since the start of this year.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- President Yeltsin's determination to push through reforms, demonstrated at the defence Council meeting yesterday, is likely to be developed in other ministries.
- Grigory Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko group, is regaining political influence and his team may yet join the government.
ROSSIISKAYA GAZETA
- Defence Minister Igor Rovionov terrified everybody with his predictions of the army's collapse, so President Yeltsin had nothing else to do but to sack him, the paper says.
PRADVA-5
- The people of Russia and Belarus need a union, which would be a union of equal and soveregn states.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- Some important international agreements have been signed by Russia recently but the public has had no chance to get acquainted with the texts.
-- Svetlana Kovaleva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
